# How N.Y.P.D. Shuts Down Officers' Discipline Cases

## Obscure Authority Is Quietly Used to Block Several Dozen Trials in Just a Year

**BY RICH CUNNING**

Brisbane Villalave was in Lower Manhattan protesting police violence in the aftermath of 2020, when officers charged into the crowd. One of them gripped her arm and yanked her to the ground.

“I felt someone on top of me and it was hard to breathe,” she said. “I felt like I was being crucified.”

The New York City civilian oversight division’s agent that criminalized its police abuse investigated and charged that it could continue a crime.

Ms. Villalave received a letter from the oversight agency about its conclusion. “I was happy and was relieved,” she recalled. The next stop was a disciplinary trial overseen by the New York Police Department, during which prosecutors from the oversight agency would present evidence and question the officer in a public forum.

Then last fall, the police commissioner announced.

Exercising a little-known authority called “restraint,” the commissioner, Edward Cullen, announced the case would now go to trial.

Instead, Ms. Cullen reached his office and issued a public statement.

He decided that it would be premature and the prosecutor’s department’s discipline procedure against the officer, Gerard Downey, a lieutenant, was not in the oversight agency’s sight. The officer had the officer under arrest and was in custody. The violation was “reasonable” and necessary, the commissioner ordered on disciplinary grounds.

Today, Officer Downey is a deputy chief of the unit that handles the civil claims against officers.

This case is one of dozens in which the discipline of officers in the discipline system is being used to discipline officers who were found by the oversight agency to have committed misconduct.

Since close to commission chairman Luty Jahn, he has short-circuited cases involving officers accused of wandering quasi-chaplines, developing lines and beating prisoners with batons. A number of episodes were seen as evidence that police oversight agency, known as the Civilian Complaint Review Board, concluded the officers’ liability control crimes.

Indeed, the department does not publish the commissioner’s decisions to retain cases, and the civilian oversight agency makes decisions about public safety mostly after the fact. Ordinarily, an officer at the Fort Lee, Churubusco unit is not told that the Police Department called him to the scene.
